descript.abstract: World Transport Network Density, 1996 is a polygon theme representing the density of major transportation routes worldwide.
descript.purpose: For educational, non-commercial purposes. This dataset is appropriate for use in a GIS.
descript.supplinf: Transportation performs specific functions. Most important, it generates impulses for economic and social development and it serves as an indicator of a region's social and economic characteristics. A well-developed transport network can increase a region's ability to compete for population and economic development. The density of the transport network is typically used to evaluate the transport provision of a region, which is a qualitative and quantitative measure of transport development. Transport provision is an integral characteristic of a region.

idinfo.native: Microsoft Windows XP Version 5.1 (Build 2600) Service Pack 3; ESRI ArcCatalog 9.3.1.1850

procstep.procdesc:
The isolines of transport network density were charted using an irregular network of control points with an operator (i.e., a glancing window, or circle). The control points were characteristic map features, such as points of maximum or minimum transport density, transport junctions, and settlements. The circle was placed on the map on the control points, and the density of the transport network was calculated. The result was a field of numbers from which the transport isolines were charted. The size of the circle was experimentally determined. The distance units used for each kind of transport were converted to railway distance equivalent by passing capacity.
This process allowed us to identify six characteristic classes of transport development for the map: (1) practically undeveloped (areas with less than 1 kilometer of transport route per 100 square kilometers), (2) poorly developed (1 to 10 km/100 sq. km), (3) scarce (10 to 20 km/100 sq. km), (4) rare (20 to 40 km/100 sq. km), (5) dense (40 to 60 km/100 sq. km), and (6) very dense (60 to 80 or more km/100 sq. km). References:
Afrika: Politicheskaya karta (Africa: Political map), 1:7,500,000. 1983. GUGK, Moscow. 2 s.
Annual bulletin of Transport Statistics for Europe. 1992. New York. 218 pp.
Australia: Tourist Map, 1:5,000,000. 1989. Tropical Publication Pty. Ltd., Cairns. 1 s.
Avtodorozhnaya karta Evropy (Road map of Europe), 1:3,500,000. 1991. VKF LenVO, St. Petersburg. 1 s.
Azia: Politicheskaya karta (Asia: Political map), 1:12,500,000. 1989. GUGK, Moscow. 1 s.
Erdol Weltatlas. 1966. Mayer F. Georg Westermann Verlag, Brannschweig. 152 s.
Geograficheskiy atlas dlya uchiteley sredney shkoly (Geographical atlas for middle school teachers). 1985. GUGK, Moscow. 238 pp.
Karta mira (Map of the world), 1:2,500,000. 1967-1976. GUGK, Moscow. Multiple sheets.
Railway Directory and Year Book 1988. 1988. A Railway Gazette international publication, London. 348 pp.
Severnaya Amerika: Politicheskaya karta (North America: Political map), 1:10,000,000. 1991. GUGK, Moscow. 1 s.
South America: An International Travel Map, 1:4,000,000. 1986- 1989. Vancouver. 4 maps.
Today's World: A new world atlas from the cartographers of Rand McNally. 1992. Rand McNally, Chicago, New York, San Francisco. 192 pp.
Transportnaya set' SSSR -- dlya vysshykh uchebnykh zavedeniy (Transport network of the USSR -- for high schools), 1:4,000,000. 1989. GUGK, Moscow. 4 s.
Yuzhnaya Amerika: Politicheskaya karta (South America: Political map), 1:10,000,000. 1986. GUGK, Moscow. 1 s.
Datasets for each continent were converted from ESRI coverage to the ESRI shapefile format using the 'copy features' tool and merged into one layer using the 'merge' tool.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The lowest density of the transport network within an area, measured in kilometers of route per 100 square kilometers of land area.
The highest density of the transport network within an area, measured in kilometers of route per 100 square kilometers of land area.
